title: TSMC Sailed Through 2020 in Ship Shape
text:
TSMC just logged another bumper quarter: Net profit for the three months ended in December rose 23% from a year earlier. That brought full-year profit to a record $17.6 billion, a 50% increase from 2019.

Strong demand helped TSMC, which makes chips for companies like Apple and Nvidia. Stay-at-home demand led to a boom in personal computers and servers used in data centers. Also, 5G smartphones and base stations added to chip demand.

TSMC sailed smoothly through the Trump administration's ban on Huawei, previously an important customer. China accounted for only 6% of TSMC's revenue last quarter, compared with 22% a year earlier. Orders from Apple and Taiwanese chip company MediaTek, which supplies many Chinese phone makers, probably helped to offset the blow.

The sudden jump in demand led to tight supply for chips throughout the year. Shortages forced some car makers to delay production. TSMC's revenue from the automotive sector grew 27% last quarter, though the segment accounted for only 3% of its revenue. The supply constraints helped TSMC: The company managed to expand its net profit margin last quarter by 2.9 percentage points compared with a year earlier.

The chip shortage means a record year of investment ahead for TSMC as well. It expects $25 billion to $28 billion in capital spending this year, a 45% to 62% increase from 2020. Semiconductor-equipment makers like ASML Holding will benefit.

Those investments mean TSMC is confident about its future. One potential new customer could be Intel, which is considering outsourcing some of its production in the most-chip-advanced nodes. Bernstein estimates capturing 20% of Intel's production needs could boost TSMC's revenue 8%. But even if Intel decides against outsourcing, TSMC could benefit from AMD's rising market share, says Bernstein. AMD, a TSMC customer, has been eroding Intel's market share in CPUs.

TSMC's shares are trading at 29 times forward earnings, after gaining 79% since the beginning of 2020. That might seem pricey, but the company is spending a lot of cash to maintain its technological edge -- add in growing demand and the struggles of competitors, and that premium valuation looks a bit less hard to swallow.
